description: {"blocks":[{"key":"ce0mt","text":"This protocol details the Ponisio Lab's collecting protocol for the 2022 Moldenke re-survey of the southern transect. Each site consists of two 900m long transects, marked every 100m with flagging tape and a nail. Each transect has three 10mÂ² vegetation plots set ~10 m off at the beginning, middle and end of each transect. At some sites this placement of vegetation plots was not possible due to terrain so site maps/GPS points should be referenced. During a site visit passive traps are placed on one transect, and active netting and vegetation surveys are done on the other transect. The activities associated with each transect alternate every site visit.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

Just chill in the car and enjoy the scenery if it is too cold or windy to sample in the early morning. If the weather gets bad throughout the day before 4 hours has passed, record how long the pans were out on the weather sheet, collect them, and finish the remainder the next day. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a6s9u","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"80ejf","text":"Set up: ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":8}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7reti","text":"1. Add 1mL of dish soap (can be prepared in eppendorf vials already) into 1L of water. Shake vigorously to mix the soap and water in the 1L bottle. Repeat with the other two bottles. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"230i9","text":"2. Record the weather on the trap weather datasheet","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6eom5","text":"3. Navigate to the beginning of the transect and place either a vane trap or group of three pan traps (one of each color) ~1m from the nail and flagging tape or wherever there is flat ground. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"eij00","text":"4. Fill vane traps with ~5cm of soapy water (about the height of 3 fingers). Fill pan traps halfway with soapy water and space ~10cm apart from each other.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"al6ig","text":"5. Place a vane or group of pan traps every 100 m along the transect, alternating between trap type (ex. if you place a vane trap at the first point, put pan traps at the second, and then a vane trap at the third, etc.) Pan traps are placed on the ground in a cluster, about 6-12 inches apart.  Vane traps should be hung at vegetation height or placed on the ground ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"989m4","text":"6. Leave the traps out for 4 hours. During that time you should net and also do vegetation sampling if there is time. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":27,"length":7}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

This can be done while setting up the traps.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9g507","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"erbnt","text":"Note: you can only net when the temperature is between 18-32C (65-90F) and the windspeed is below 2.5 m/s.Â ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":107}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5q55t","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8nqc4","text":"Navigate to the beginning of the other transect(not the transect you put the traps on). ","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3m4us","text":"Check that your stopwatch is set to Countdown and shows 100 minutes.  ","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":56,"length":11}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fmcnj","text":"Start your stopwatch and begin looking for bees. You will stop the stopwatch every time you catch a bee, and start it again after you have put the bee in a vial and are ready to begin searching for a new specimen (so you are not counting any time to get the bee out of the net, into a vial, or labeled in the sampling time). Start your stopwatch and slowly walk towards the second point on the transect so that it takes you 10 minutes (of active search time) to cover 100 m. You should zigzag a bit so that you cover a few meters on either side of the transect and donât just walk in a perfectly straight line.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":423,"length":52}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e2god","text":"You should collect any pollinating insect that touches the reproductive parts of a flower within your assigned subsite. ","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":193,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"j9lm","text":"If you get a particularly pollen-covered insect that smears pollen all over your net,  spray the bag with bleach (destroy pollen), wait 30 seconds, then ethanol )helps evaporation). Wave it around to dry it. ","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d0d8v","text":"You should ignore any beetles that you know do not pollinate (just sitting in the flower), hemipterans, grasshoppers, ants, ladybugs, spiders, etc. Do not collect an insect if it is just sitting on the petals or leaves --only if it seems to be foraging and actively engaging in pollination.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":11,"length":279}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2jks6","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3d6bm","text":"Once you have a specimen in your net, stop your stopwatch and transfer it into a vial. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":58}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5bsou","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f2sq5","text":"Unsure of a plant ID? If you are not sure about the flower,  create a temporary plant code based on the information you know such as color and family (small, white, 5-petals, opposite leaves), then you must write a description of the plant in as much detail as possible, and take multiple photos. Use the Unknown plant datasheet to write the description. Upload the photos to the iNaturalist and to Dropbox labeled with the code you used on vials and the site (i.e., thistle_white_AnzaO). Update the unknown plant datasheet you have an ID from iNaturalist. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":305,"length":24},{"style":"bold","offset":355,"length":37},{"style":"bold","offset":399,"length":7},{"style":"bold","offset":487,"length":2}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"94ovl","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"87ns4","text":"Store the collected insect in your fanny pack on an ice pack, to keep the insect cool and calm. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bab2r","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fk458","text":"A note about flower labeling:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":28}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c6hao","text":"For this project, we use a labeling system for flowers in which we only write the first three letters of the genus and species (so Hymenoxys hoopesii becomes \"HYMHOO\"). ","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3kjn5","text":"Count the vials. Place a cap sticker on the first vial and last vial. Do not pick the traps up earlier than 4 hours, unless it rains and they need to be collected early. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":37,"length":8}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"65hok","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a8ia7","text":"Note: if the weather becomes inappropriate for sampling (i.e. temperature drops below 17C, windspeed goes over 2.5m/s, it becomes too overcast to cast a shadow, or begins to rain), make a note of the times that it is inadequate sampling weather on the Pan Weather sheet. Any time that is not appropriate for sampling does not count toward the 4 hours of pan trap time (so for instance, if you put out the pan traps at 10:00am, and at 12:30, it begins raining and rains until 1:00pm, you need to add an extra half hour to the pan trap time, so instead of picking them up at 2:30, you will pick them up at 3:00).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"df039","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9v3pu","text":"Once you have determined that it is time to collect pan traps, take the weather and note it on the pan weather sheet. ","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5e7sl","text":" Fill out the pan trap labelsÂ using a micron penÂ and take a bag of non-sterile vials filled with ethanol. {"blocks":[{"key":"1fufh","text":"Supplies:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"29u6f","text":"Plant survey datasheet","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":22}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cl2mb","text":"pen/pencil","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"32cqb","text":"plant guides","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"23ahn","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e4kca","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3gbi8","text":"Vegetation surveys are not timed or weather-sensitive and can be before, in between, or after pollinator surveys. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4d6gp","text":"Each site has a total of six vegetation plots (6 one each transect) but only the three will be sampled during a site visit. Update the unknown data sheet with the final ID.  ","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":69,"length":24}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3aggc","text":"For each plant recorded, you will also record bloom description, count of individuals, and number of blooms. ","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2inam","text":"While not all individuals in the plot may not be at the exact same stage of blooming, record what characterizes the majority of individuals. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7pdfu","text":" Counts of individuals should be as specific as possible but can be rounded with large numbers of individuals. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"58d6u","text":"Tightly packed inflorescences should be counted as a single bloom.
